title: Capture is complete and reliable
description: No gaps in what gets logged - cookies, headers, bodies all present
design:
## Vision
What chrome-log captures matches what you'd see in DevTools Network tab - no surprises, no missing data.

## Child Tasks
- scl-4ec.2: Audit capture completeness

## Known Intentional Gaps
- Binary bodies (images, fonts) - skipped to save space
- Very large bodies - truncated at 100KB
- Tracking/analytics requests - filtered out
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Cookies captured for all requests
- [ ] Headers captured (request and response)
- [ ] Bodies captured for JSON/text (with size limits)
- [ ] Gaps documented in CLAUDE.md
- [ ] All child tasks complete

title: Investigate missing cookies in logs
description: Cookies aren't appearing in network logs - may be security filtering in CDP. Research and fix if possible.
close_reason: Fixed - cookies now captured via CDP Network.requestWillBeSentExtraInfo and responseReceivedExtraInfo events

title: Audit capture completeness
description: Systematic check: what else might be missing? Compare CDP capture vs browser DevTools Network tab for same requests.
design:
## Approach
Side-by-side comparison:
1. Open page in Chrome Debug with DevTools Network tab visible
2. Compare what DevTools shows vs what `chrome-log tail` shows
3. Identify any gaps

## Known Limitations (document, don't fix)
- Binary bodies (images, fonts) - intentionally skipped
- Very large bodies (>100KB) - truncated
- Streaming responses - may be incomplete

## Potential Gaps to Check
- WebSocket messages
- Service Worker requests
- Preflight CORS requests
- Redirects (do we capture both?)
- Request bodies for all methods (not just POST)
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Compare 10+ diverse requests (API, static, redirect, etc.)
- [ ] Document any gaps found
- [ ] File follow-up beads for fixable gaps
- [ ] Update CLAUDE.md "Risks" section with known limitations

title: Add --yes flag to install script
description: Install script should accept --yes or -y flag to skip confirmation prompts. Enables non-interactive setup.
design:
## Approach
Add argument parsing to install.sh:
- `--yes` or `-y` flag sets non-interactive mode
- Skip all confirmation prompts
- Fail fast on errors (no "press any key")

## Use Cases
- CI/CD pipelines
- Scripted setup (e.g., from another installer)
- Power users who know what they want
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] `./install.sh --yes` runs without prompts
- [ ] `./install.sh -y` works as alias
- [ ] Still shows what it's doing (not silent)
- [ ] Exits non-zero on any failure
- [ ] Without flag, behavior unchanged (still prompts)

title: Add chrome-log restart command
description: CLI should support 'chrome-log restart' to stop and start daemon in one command. Currently requires separate stop/start.
design:
## Approach
Add 'restart' subcommand to chrome-log.py that:
1. Calls stop logic
2. Waits for clean shutdown (check PID file gone)
3. Calls start logic

## Edge Cases
- Daemon not running: just start
- Daemon hung: force kill after timeout, then start
- Chrome not running: start daemon anyway (it will wait for connection)
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] `chrome-log restart` stops then starts daemon
- [ ] Works when daemon is running
- [ ] Works when daemon is not running (just starts)
- [ ] Handles hung daemon gracefully (timeout + force kill)
- [ ] Exit code 0 on success

title: Server quits with Chrome
description: Revisit the decision to keep status server running when Chrome quits. Current reasoning: enables auto-reconnect on pinned status tab. Cleaner alternative: let server quit too, status page shows 'not running', both restart together with chrome-debug. Investigate if the UX is actually worse.
design:
## Current Behavior
- Daemon exits when Chrome quits (clean)
- Status server stays running (enables auto-reconnect)

## Alternative: Server Also Quits
- Cleaner resource usage
- Status page would show connection error until restart
- User must manually refresh after chrome-debug restart

## Investigation Needed
1. How annoying is the "connection error" UX when server is down?
2. Does auto-reconnect actually work well enough to justify keeping server alive?
3. Is there a middle ground (server stays for N minutes then exits)?

## Decision Framework
Keep current if: auto-reconnect UX is noticeably better
Change if: the "orphan server" feels wrong and reconnect isn't that useful
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Test current auto-reconnect UX (pin status tab, quit Chrome, restart chrome-debug)
- [ ] Test alternative UX (kill server too, observe reconnect behavior)
- [ ] Document decision with reasoning
- [ ] If changing: update daemon.py to also stop server on Chrome disconnect
- [ ] If keeping: document rationale in CLAUDE.md

title: Create tested setup flow for new users
description: End-to-end setup script that a fresh user can run. Test on a sprite or clean environment.
design:
## Approach
Create install.sh that handles everything:
1. Check prerequisites (Python 3.9+, Chrome)
2. Create Chrome Debug app bundle (or verify existing)
3. Install Python dependencies (uv sync)
4. Set up launchd plist
5. Add chrome-debug and chrome-log to PATH
6. Verify installation works

## Test Environment
- Fresh macOS (use sprite or VM)
- No prior chrome-log installation
- Verify from git clone to working tool

## User Experience
- Single command: `./install.sh`
- Clear progress messages
- Helpful error messages if something fails
- Final success message with "try this" command
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] `git clone && cd && ./install.sh` works on fresh Mac
- [ ] Prerequisites checked with clear error messages
- [ ] Chrome Debug.app created/verified
- [ ] launchd plist installed correctly
- [ ] `chrome-debug` and `chrome-log` commands work after install
- [ ] Tested on sprite or clean environment
- [ ] Uninstall path documented (or uninstall.sh provided)

title: Logger tab auto-opens and pins on debug Chrome launch
description: When Chrome Debug starts, localhost:9223 should open as a pinned tab automatically.
design:
## Approach
Modify chrome-debug script (or Chrome Debug.app launch) to:
1. Start Chrome with --remote-debugging-port
2. Wait for Chrome to be ready
3. Open localhost:9223 as a new tab
4. Pin that tab

## Technical Options
1. **AppleScript after launch** - Tell Chrome to open URL and pin
2. **Chrome startup URL** - Pass --app=http://localhost:9223 (but can't pin)
3. **Extension** - Auto-pin on specific URL (overkill)

## Challenges
- Chrome takes time to start - need to wait
- Pinning requires AppleScript or extension
- Status server must be running first
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] `chrome-debug` command opens Chrome Debug
- [ ] Status page tab appears automatically
- [ ] Tab is pinned (leftmost position)
- [ ] Works on fresh launch (not just when Chrome already running)
- [ ] No manual steps required

title: Chrome Log daemon shows proper name in Login Items
description: Currently shows as 'python' with 'Item from unidentified developer' warning in macOS Login Items & Extensions.
design:
## Approach
Bundle the daemon as a proper macOS .app with:
- Info.plist declaring CFBundleName, CFBundleIdentifier
- Wrapper script as CFBundleExecutable that invokes the Python daemon
- Icon (can reuse/adapt the Chrome Debug hue-shifted icon)

## Structure
```
Chrome Log Daemon.app/
  Contents/
    Info.plist          # CFBundleName = "Chrome Log"
    MacOS/
      chrome-log-daemon # Shell wrapper â†’ python scripts/daemon.py
    Resources/
      AppIcon.icns
```

## Code Signing Options
1. **Ad-hoc signing** (`codesign -s -`): Removes "unidentified developer", shows "signed locally"
2. **Developer ID** (requires Apple account): Full trust, no warnings
3. **No signing**: Current state, shows warnings

## launchd Integration
Update plist to run the .app bundle instead of python directly:
```xml
<key>ProgramArguments</key>
<array>
  <string>/path/to/Chrome Log Daemon.app/Contents/MacOS/chrome-log-daemon</string>
</array>
```
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Login Items shows "Chrome Log" instead of "python"
- [ ] No "unidentified developer" warning (ad-hoc signing minimum)
- [ ] Daemon starts/stops correctly via launchd
- [ ] `chrome-log status` still works
- [ ] App bundle lives in sensible location (~/Applications or within repo)

title: Skill works naturally in conversation
description: Claude can use the skill fluidly when users ask about network traffic
design:
## Vision
When a user asks Claude about network traffic from their browsing, Claude reaches for chrome-log naturally - no explicit invocation needed.

## Child Tasks
- scl-su0.1: Polish skill writing
- scl-su0.2: Test natural activation

## Success State
User: "What API did YouTube just call?"
Claude: *automatically uses chrome-log tail, finds relevant requests, explains*
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Skill triggers on natural questions about network traffic
- [ ] Claude interprets results correctly (not just dumps)
- [ ] Error cases handled gracefully in skill
- [ ] All child tasks complete

title: Polish skill writing
description: Review SKILL.md for clarity, examples, and natural language triggers. Make it easy for Claude to know when/how to use.
design:
## Review Areas
1. **Trigger phrases** - What should make Claude reach for this skill?
2. **Examples** - Are they realistic and helpful?
3. **Command reference** - Clear, complete, well-organized?
4. **Error handling** - Does skill explain what to do when things fail?

## Style Goals
- Natural language, not robotic
- Show don't tell (examples > explanation)
- Anticipate common questions
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Trigger section has realistic phrases ("what API did that call?", "show me the network traffic")
- [ ] At least 3 worked examples showing realistic use
- [ ] All CLI commands documented with examples
- [ ] Error scenarios covered (daemon not running, no matches, etc.)
- [ ] Read through feels natural, not like a man page

title: Test natural skill activation
description: Real-world test: load a page in debug browser, ask Claude 'what endpoint did that use?' - verify skill activates and finds the answer.
design:
## Test Scenario
1. Start Chrome Debug, browse to a site with interesting APIs (e.g., YouTube, Twitter)
2. Start fresh Claude session
3. Ask naturally: "what endpoint did that page call?" or "show me the API requests"
4. Verify Claude activates skill and finds answer

## Success Criteria
- Claude recognizes this is a chrome-log question
- Claude runs appropriate `chrome-log` commands
- Claude interprets results correctly
- Answer is useful to the user

## Failure Modes to Watch
- Claude tries to use DevTools instead
- Claude asks user to copy/paste from browser
- Claude misinterprets the log format
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Test with 3+ different sites/APIs
- [ ] Claude activates skill without explicit prompting
- [ ] Claude finds correct endpoints in logs
- [ ] Claude explains what the API does (not just dumps raw data)
- [ ] Document any activation failures for skill tuning
